posts.content:
In a world that can often make us feel like we are expected to know everything, there is freedom in admitting the honest truth: that we don't! 

With every
comes an opportunity to learn something new.

Stay curious, ask questions, seek out new perspectives, and celebrate growth that comes from discovery.

hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety doesn't mean people are always comfortable and conversations are always easy. It's about the ability to have those tough conversations that lead to growth without fear of repercussions.

Fantastic piece byabout the perils of equating "nice" with having high emotional intelligence (and high psychological safety), featuring research from myself,, and.

Read in:

hashtag
#PsychologicalSafety is a win-win-win.

When employees feel safe and supported bringing their full selves to the tableâ€”all their thoughts, ideas, questions, and (yes) flawsâ€”it lifts up the people, the work, and the company...

Excited to have Vanessa Druskat's fantastic new book in my hands. A great resource for anyone interested in building resilient

#teams.

This provocative and smart article by Gautam Mukunda is worth a read.

So thrilled to have this wonderful book in my hands, hot off the press. Labwork to Leadership by Jen Heemstra is an absolutely invaluable guide for scientific leaders everywhere.

If you've read
, you might recognize Jen from the beginning of Chapter 2: Eureka! Her interview on learning and discovery in the lab was a perfect intro for explaining
.

"I want to create a campus culture where failure is reframed as an essential component of learning, innovation and personal growth."

This brings me such joy! I love seeing colleges working to help students develop the intellectual and emotional skills they need to navigate uncertainty and
.

Kudos to, Dean of Engaged Education at, and the ALEX department for this wonderful initiative.

Read more here:

I'm proud to share the new article with my amazing coauthors Nicki Macklin and Tom Lee. 

It's Nicki whose important research on
inspired us to
and share insights about how kindness drives
and
â€” and why it matters.

Psychologists and neuroscientists have discovered that, far too often for our own health and success, a kind of automatic sense that we're right blinds usâ€”the confirmation bias. We literally fail to see evidence that goes against what we believe.

But being wrong is part of being alive in a complex and uncertain world.

The best antidote to this type of thinking is to be curious, and to be humble. Prioritize learning over knowing. Seek out other perspectives. Ask yourself: how do I know that I'm right?

Don't know where to start when building a psychologically safe workplace?

Here's the advice I gaveon how HR leaders can implement practices that will benefit teams and organizations at every level.

Of course, this is just a starting point. I'd love to hear what strategies have worked for you!

What an honor from The Business Excellence Institute! To be recognized for my work is always a pinch-me moment.

I'd love to see some familiar faces at the induction this September in Dublinâ€¦if you'll be in the area, grab a ticket:

Now this is excellence! Reframing (let's face it, critical) feedback as a kind of complimentâ€”the person felt able (yes, safe) to convey her concerns. 

Beautiful story fromby

An eagerness to learn is essential for innovation. 

But the way we learnâ€”and the order in which we partake in various learning activitiesâ€”can make the difference between effective growth and potential missed opportunities.

,,, and I studied more than 160 innovation teams and found that the key to faster, clearer progress is:

Structured learning ğŸ‘·ğŸ—ï¸

Our research, published in theJournal, highlights four distinct types of learning behaviors used by high-performing teams and examines variations in the sequence and blend of these types of team learning.

Without a deliberate rhythm, teams risk becoming overwhelmed by continual information intake, leading to confusion and burnout. But by honing a team's ideal 'learning rhythm,' you can avoid overwhelm and instead focus on strategic decision-making and sustainable innovation.

Read our research summary now in the:

Elite failure practitioners around the world and throughout historyâ€”athletes, inventors, entrepreneurs, scientistsâ€”have taught me a great deal about what it takes to be tolerant to failures of all kinds. 

What motivates EFPs to endure and befriend failure?

An unrelenting drive to solve new problems that advance their craftâ€”not through philosophic contemplation, but by interacting with the world around them. Testing things out. Experimenting. Theyâ€™re willing to act!

The good news? We all have the ability to foster this unique mix of skills necessary for
within ourselves.

ğ—ªğ—µğ˜† ğ—±ğ—¼ ğ˜€ğ—¼ğ—ºğ—² ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—»ğ—¼ğ˜ƒğ—®ğ˜ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ—» ğ˜ğ—²ğ—®ğ—ºğ˜€ ğ—±ğ—²ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—¿ ğ˜„ğ—µğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—² ğ—¼ğ˜ğ—µğ—²ğ—¿ğ˜€ ğ˜€ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¹ğ—¹â€”ğ—±ğ—²ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—² ğ˜„ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¸ğ—¶ğ—»ğ—´ ğ—·ğ˜‚ğ˜€ğ˜ ğ—®ğ˜€ ğ—µğ—®ğ—¿ğ—±?

In research conducted with,, and, we studied more than 160 innovation teamsâ€”including those in a Fortune Global 500 companyâ€”and found that it's not just how much teams learn that matters, but when and how they learn.

We identified four core modes of team learning:
ğ—¥ğ—²ğ—³ğ—¹ğ—²ğ˜…ğ—¶ğ˜ƒğ—² â€” assessing goals, roles, and strategies
ğ—˜ğ˜…ğ—½ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—ºğ—²ğ—»ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¹ â€” brainstorming, prototyping, testing new ideas
ğ—–ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜ğ—²ğ˜…ğ˜ğ˜‚ğ—®ğ—¹ â€” scanning the environment for trends, signals, and shifts
ğ—©ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—®ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—¼ğ˜‚ğ˜€ â€” drawing lessons from others whoâ€™ve done similar work

The most effective teams didnâ€™t try to do everything at once. They began and ended with reflexive learning, anchoring their work in shared understanding. They placed exploratory learning (experimental and contextual) in the middle. This rhythmâ€”reflection â†’ exploration â†’ reflectionâ€”helped them reduce friction, integrate insights, and build real momentum.

We also found that vicarious learning can be combined with reflexive learning in the same project phase with positive results. But when teams mixed reflexive with experimental or contextual learning in the same phase, performance suffered.

ğ—§ğ—µğ—² ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¸ğ—²ğ—®ğ˜„ğ—®ğ˜†: Innovation doesnâ€™t thrive on more learning. It thrives on structured learning. Teams that sequence and separate their learning activities make faster, clearer progress.

Weâ€™ve summarized the findings from our research, published inâ€”a leading journal in organizational researchâ€”in this newarticle. Link in comments.
Great piece by IMD with a spot on call out about Satya Nadella's feedback-seeking to build a culture of learn-it-alls.

The best leaders show up as learners, not as know-it-alls. 

I spoke with Rodger Dean Duncan on the LeaderSHOP podcast all about how to build a culture where people speak up, learn from
, and work through uncertainty.

Listen here:

Angela Duckworth has identified a paradox in AI and education... I think it can best be described as a trap. The ever-present trap of choosing easy options today only to discover that you'll pay for it later. Our challenge is how to help ourselves and others avoid such traps by rediscovering the motivation and the desire to do hard things today.

Too often, we go into important conversations ready to argue our point without stopping to ask what we might be missing. 

shares a practical tool to help leaders pause, reflect, and enter tough moments with more
and less certainty...a great read for anyone looking to improve their curiosity muscle!

Read in:

A small nugget from my conversation with the folks at Workhuman. 

Building a truly fearless org requires work at all levels. Education, leadership messaging, and feedback are great ways to start!

When we talk about 
hashtag
#burnout, the focus is often on workload, boundaries, or other tangible obstacles that inform our common perception of what 'overworked' can look like. 

But the emotional and cognitive exhaustion that comes with interpersonal anxiety also plays a large role.

When teams lack
â€”that is, when they feel unsafe speaking up, asking for help, raising questions, or flagging problemsâ€”employees are much more likely to experience workplace stress, and eventually, burnout.

I explore this topic and more with the wonderfulfor his Culture Matters podcastâ€¦take a listen at the link:

Second place can feel disastrous, but the sting of â€œalmostâ€ is less a verdict on your potential than an invitation to hone it. 

Coming up just short can serve as a springboard for growth, offering the chance to learn, adapt, and come back strongerâ€”provided you choose to seize the opportunity.

My new article, written with the inimitable, is all about how our near misses can teach us more than our successes.

Another great article by Jim Detert - his unique blend of insight, rigor, and practical suggestions shines through this new guide to speaking up and standing up. With specific phrases to experiment with (and practice), the ideas he shares can, and should be put to immediate use.
Magnificent post.
Thanks Jay Lau for this terrific summary from the Harvard Chan School of Public Health Michaela Kerrissey

Learning from setbacks, both small and large, is part of the science of failing well.

Mistakes creep in despite access to foolproof knowledge about what to do to get the result you want. Maybe you forget to set the timer and burn the cookies. Maybe your mistake leads to more severe consequences.

Humans are fallible. Mistakes will happen. Once you accept this truth, you can begin the important work of learning from
.

ğŸ“•

How do you feel about failure?

a) Doesnâ€™t bother me
b) Ok but Iâ€™d rather not
c) Uncomfortable and want to avoid
d) Not an option for me

This was the question I put to a group of leaders in a recent training session with a new client this week. The responses were fascinatingâ€”and telling.

Many chose c.

And thatâ€™s completely understandable. As leaders, weâ€™re often under pressure to have the answers, to deliver results, and to â€˜get it rightâ€™. But hereâ€™s the thing:
âš ï¸ If failure isnâ€™t an option, neither is learning. âš ï¸

What we explored together in that session was this:
If we want growth and better leadershipâ€”we need an appetite for failure. Not recklessness, but a genuine willingness to experiment, get things wrong, and learn fast. I'm talking aboutand her idea of intelligent failure.

The leaders who grow the most are the ones who can say:
"I didnâ€™t get that rightâ€”and hereâ€™s what I learned."

They're also the leaders who enable the development of others because they create a safe space where others can also try things out, take measured risks, learn and grow without fear of judgement or retribution.

So, how do YOU feel about failure? And more importantlyâ€”what are you doing to build a culture where itâ€™s not just tolerated, but seen as essential for progress?

Iâ€™d love to hear your thoughts ğŸ‘‡ type your answer to my question above - a,b,c or d in the comments below.

- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Being a manager or a founder shouldnâ€™t be ğŸ’©

I work with managers, leaders, founders and their businesses using coaching and training to ensure that it isnâ€™t.

I ensure that individuals have the knowledge and awareness to embrace their roles with energy and enjoyment, connect with their confidence and capabilities, and take control of their development and growth, to ensure that they thrive for themselves, their teams, and their businesses.

Because when we enjoy what we do, we do a great job. Itâ€™s that simple.

If you missed my keynote at the fantastic Association for Talent Development (ATD) conference in Washington DC last month, here's a fun (and functional) overview. 

Such remarkable talent from artist, who so effortlessly captured ideas from my talk in real time!

â€œAre you nuts? Iâ€™m an accountant.â€
Thatâ€™s what one employee thought when she was handed the game controller to pilot a deep-sea sub.

I just watched Titan: The OceanGate Disaster, a story that goes far beyond technology or engineering.

Five lives lost. A vision so bold it became untouchable.
A culture that dismissed concerns and punished dissent.

How do you fire your chief pilot for raising safety concerns?
Why reject third-party safety reviews in the name of â€œinnovationâ€?
When does confidence become arrogance?
How often do we confuse disagreement with disloyalty?

â€™s research on psychological safety reminds us: when people donâ€™t feel safe to speak up, risk grows silently, sometimes with tragic consequences.

What am I holding back?
How many people in my team are staying quiet?
And what does that say about the culture we're helping build?

These are the questions that stay with me long after the credits roll.
